title: Boeing Didn't Get Any Commercial 737 Orders Last Month
summary: Plane maker delivered fewer MAX jets last month, after fatal crashes prompted grounding of aircraft. Boeing Co. didn't book any commercial orders for its 737 jetliner in March, the first month without a sale of the aerospace giant's best-selling aircraft in almost seven years.

title: Questioning the Four-Year College Degree
summary: Though overvalued by employers, it's not the only path to success.. Editor's note: This Future View is about the emphasis American society places on the four-year college degree. Next week we'll discuss an increasingly common sight on social media: the mass denunciation of a person judged to have done wrong. We'll ask, "Are social-media mobs democracy in action, or a threat to democracy?" Students should click here to submit opinions of fewer than 250 words before April 16. The best responses will be published that night.

title: Incoherent on Immigration
summary: Firing his own deputies won't help the border or move Congress.. Frustrated with Congress and the courts on border security, President Trump has responded by firing his own immigration-enforcement deputies. This political incoherence won't produce better results at the border or break the stalemate in Congress over immigration.

title: Andrew Marshall
summary: The Pentagon strategist who saw the military threats of the future..

title: The Antitrust Avengers
summary: Trump's enforcers seem to be gluttons for legal embarrassment.. The Justice Department's antitrust avengers are back. After losing its appeal to block the AT&T -Time Warner merger, the government is now taking on the Hollywood cartel known as the Oscars in the name of protecting little guys like Netflix and Amazon.

title: The Euroskeptics Unite, Sort Of
summary: A new populist party wants to force a debate about Europe's future.. Plenty of European politicians are adept at talking like euroskeptics. All the more credit, then, to Italy's Matteo Salvini for launching a Europe-wide political movement that could force a debate about the future of Europe.

title: Senate Republicans Skeptical of Cain's Fed Confirmation Chances
summary: Former restaurant executive suggests opposition to proposed nomination for Fed is based on his conservative views. WASHINGTON-Senate Republicans sounded increasingly doubtful Tuesday about the prospects of confirming President Trump's latest pick for the Federal Reserve Board, former GOP presidential candidate Herman Cain, who has dismissed criticism of his candidacy as partisan.

title: Norsk Hydro Repairs Systems and Investigates After Ransomware Attack
summary: Norwegian aluminum and energy company confirms LockerGoga virus was used in strike that crippled operations. Norwegian aluminum and energy company Norsk Hydro AS A confirmed that hackers used a relatively new form of ransomware known as LockerGoga in a March 19 cyberattack that crippled the company's global operations.

title: Splits Among House Democrats Derail Spending Vote
summary: Ideologically diverse group of lawmakers can't agree on two-year plan. WASHINGTON-House Democrats were forced to skip a vote on federal spending levels in the face of opposition from progressive and centrist lawmakers, throwing a wrench in their efforts to craft an opening negotiating position with Republicans ahead of a fall deadline.

title: Socialism Fails Every Time
summary: The best outcome is a reversion to capitalism. The worst? Hundreds of millions dead.. Self-described socialist Bernie Sanders has become a favorite of young voters by posing as an apostle of daring new ideas. Socialism, however, is anything but new. It's hard to think of another idea that has been tried and failed as many times in as many ways or at a steeper price in human suffering.

title: Republicans Managed to Make ObamaCare Popular
summary: Before President Trump took office, only 43% of voters approved of the law. That's up to 50% now.. A Kaiser Family Foundation poll released in December 2016, just before President Obama left office, showed that the Affordable Care Act had a favorability rating of 43%, while 46% viewed it unfavorably. Last month, the same poll showed the nine-year-old health-insurance law well above water, with 50% viewing it positively to 39% negatively.

title: Get Ready for a Pileup, Tesla
summary: The company braces for a $300 billion onslaught of money-losing green cars.. "I would have bought my Tesla even without the tax rebate." So went any number of irate emails from readers over the years, nonsensically for any point I was trying to make. Elon Musk isn't in the business of leaving money on the table. He priced his cars to make sure every penny of subsidy ended up in Tesla's pockets and not its customers'.

title: Barr Says Release of Mueller Report Can Come Within a Week
summary: Barr vows transparency in reasons for blacking out parts of roughly 400-page document on Russian interference in the 2016 election. WASHINGTON-Attorney General William Barr said he would deliver the special counsel's still-secret report to Congress within a week and vowed to explain his reasons for blacking out parts of the roughly 400-page document, a pledge that did little to mollify demands from Democrats for full access to the report.

title: How Character Can Win the Next Election
summary: A Democrat who stays above the fray may appeal to voters across partisan lines.. Position papers don't win presidential primaries-or general elections. For most people, deciding which candidate to support for president is a personal decision, driven not only by rational calculation but by intuition and emotion. This is more true for presidential voting than for any other ballot we cast.

title: Chipping Away at the Mortgage Deduction
summary: A lesser-known benefit of the 2017 tax reform.. Less than half as many American taxpayers are claiming the mortgage-interest deduction for 2018 as did the year earlier. With any luck, the 2017 tax overhaul will prove to be only the first step toward eventually replacing the century-old housing subsidy with a more effective program.

title: Toll Roads Tax the Poor
summary: Technology makes it easy to ding drivers. No wonder politicians are seeing dollar signs.. When Hartford, Conn.'s Charter Oak Bridge opened in 1942, local officials gave 13-year-old William Thornton the ceremonial privilege of paying the first toll to cross it. On April 28, 1989, Thornton paid the last state highway toll in Connecticut as he drove across the same bridge, marking the end of a lengthy battle over toll collections on the Connecticut Turnpike, Merritt Parkway and other state roads.

title: The Worst Federal Student-Loan Program
summary: It's called PLUS, and it's especially risky for black families of limited wealth.. College debt feels out of control. Outstanding student loan-liabilities, almost all from federal loans, have more than doubled since 2009, to $1.57 trillion. News of distressed graduates with six- and even seven-figure balances abound. Some presidential candidates have called for widespread debt forgiveness and "free" college.

title: Netanyahu and His Challenger Both Declare Victory in Israeli Election
summary: Voters cast ballots as Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu seeks reelection. TEL AVIV-Both Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his challenger, former Gen. Benny Gantz, declared victory in Israel's election after a hard-fought race that underlined Israel's rightward drift and tested voters' tolerance for a leader facing corruption allegations.

title: 'The Survival of the Jews in France, 1940-44' Review: Living Under Occupation
summary: More Jews survived World War II in France than in many other European states. How much credit do their countrymen deserve?. 'In some countries, the French have the reputation of being anti-Semitic," Jacques Semelin writes in "The Survival of the Jews in France, 1940-44." It is the goal of his careful study to show that France as a nation deserves more credit for helping save the majority of its Jewish population from death during the German occupation. The figures are striking: There were about 320,000 Jews living in France in 1940, including some 135,000 immigrants. Of this total, a quarter were deported and murdered by the Nazi killing machine. But 75% survived to the end of the war-a stark contrast with countries such as Poland and the Netherlands, where the percentages were substantially reversed.

title: In Technology Stocks, Investors Do Trust
summary: The S&P 500 tech group is up 22% in 2019, compared with a 15% advance for the broader index. A group of the largest technology companies climbed to a record Monday, highlighting investors' renewed faith in software and chip companies after a fourth-quarter rout.

title: Mnuchin Says Request for Trump Tax Returns Is Being Reviewed
summary: Steven Mnuchin pushes back against suggestions Trump hasn't been transparent, saying the president has followed financial-disclosure laws. WASHINGTON-Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said his department intended to follow the law after reviewing House Democrats' request for President Trump's tax returns-though he reiterated that did not necessarily mean he would turn over the documents.

title: Stocks Close Lower as U.S. Plots New Tariffs on EU
summary: S&P 500 drop snaps the index's longest winning streak in years. The S&P 500 retreated Tuesday, snapping the broad index's longest winning streak in years, as investors confronted fresh trade tensions and further signs that economic growth around the world is slowing.

title: Fed to Review Inflation Targeting, Policy Tools and Communications
summary: Vice Chairman Richard Clarida says central bank will study letting inflation rise above 2% during booms. Federal Reserve vice chairman Richard Clarida said Tuesday that the central bank's review of its monetary policy will look at new ways to deal with low inflation as well as novel approaches to stimulate a weak economy and to communicate with the public.

title: New York City Orders Mandatory Measles Vaccinations in Parts of Brooklyn
summary: Public health emergency decree also imposes fines for noncompliance. New York City officials declared a public-health emergency as authorities elsewhere in the state announced new measures to halt the spread of measles, stepping up their responses after a recent surge in cases.

title: Cisco Names Former Thomson Reuters IT Chief as CIO
summary: Guillermo Diaz, Cisco's CIO since 2015, moves to customer-focused role. Cisco Systems Inc. has hired a leader in digital enterprise strategies as its new chief information officer amid the tech giant's growing focus on software services for renewed growth.

title: Should Trump Tweet More About Tax Cuts?
summary: Voters like the results even though polls say few people realize their taxes were cut.. The latest NBC/Wall Street Journal survey finds that while Americans continue to like Donald Trump more than they did in the fall of 2016, most U.S. adults still don't respond positively when asked to express their feelings about America's 45th President. A full 51% of respondents in the latest survey express a negative view of Mr. Trump, 40% express a positive one, and 9% hold a neutral view.

title: Levi Strauss Swings to Profit, Maintains Outlook
summary: Jeans maker reports broad-based growth across regions. Levi Strauss & Co. swung to a profit in the latest period with broad-based sales growth across regions and a sharply lower income-tax bill.

title: Top New York City School Makes Big Admissions Error
summary: NYC Lab School had to rerank applicants after an error; no offers were rescinded. A mistake in the city's high-anxiety admissions process has led the New York City Department of Education to inform 144 students that they had erroneously been denied spots in a sought-after high school and that they have been admitted after all.

title: Pompeo to Visit Colombian City on Venezuela's Border
summary: Top U.S. envoy seeks to reaffirm Washington's support for opposition leader Juan Guaidó. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo heads this week to Latin America to press the Trump administration's call for a political transition in Venezuela, underscoring the mission by visiting a city on the troubled country's border, the State Department said.

title: Gold Gains After Threat of Tariffs on Europe Imports
summary: Nervous investors seek safety as trade tensions between Brussels and Washington grow. Gold prices rose Tuesday as the Trump administration's threat to assess new tariffs on European imports sent some investors into haven assets.

title: Italy Warns of Bigger Budget Deficit
summary: Finance Ministry forecasts a 2.4% gap, wider than the 2% agreed upon with the European Union in December. ROME-Italy's populist government conceded it won't hit the budget-deficit target agreed on with European Union authorities, setting the stage for renewed tensions with Brussels.

title: NYC Firefighter Killed in Afghanistan Remembered for His Bravery
summary: Christopher Slutman 'bravely wore two uniforms and committed his life to public service,' FDNY commissioner said. A decorated New York City firefighter who was one of three U.S. Marines killed in a roadside bombing in Afghanistan was remembered Tuesday for his heroism, including rescuing an unconscious woman from a Bronx fire two years ago.

title: Former SeaWorld Attorney Pleads Guilty to Insider-Trading Charges
summary: Former associate general counsel admits to trading on advance knowledge of revenue and attendance numbers. A former attorney at SeaWorld Entertainment Inc. pleaded guilty to insider trading Tuesday, after federal prosecutors said he earned about $65,000 in profits from trading shares ahead of the public disclosure of the company's rising attendance numbers.

title: Dollar Falls Against Yen as Investors Seek Safety
summary: U.S. currency drops as investors move toward safer assets amid concerns about global growth. The dollar edged slightly lower Tuesday, driven by losses against the yen as investors shifted money to assets considered havens amid fresh concerns about the global growth outlook.

title: Wynn Resorts Ends Talks With Crown Resorts After Premature Disclosure
summary: Wynn Resorts took a $7.1 billion bid off the table as signs of a spending slowdown haunt the global gambling hub of Macau. Wynn Resorts Ltd. abruptly called-off discussions over a potential $7.1 billion offer for Australia's Crown Resorts Ltd. Tuesday, saying the takeover target had prematurely disclosed their talks.

title: Home-Buying Startup Opendoor Courting Miffed Brokers
summary: San Francisco-based company is launching an agent partnership program, deepening its reliance on the brokerage business. Opendoor, a real-estate startup that broke new ground by enabling users to buy or sell homes online with the click of a button, is moving to work more closely with the brokerage industry.

title: Casadesus: Hard to Say, Easy to Listen To
summary: A 65-CD tribute to the now-obscure French pianist Robert Casadesus highlights his broad classical repertory and reveals why he was so popular during his life..

title: Canada Wants to Limit Claims For Some Asylum Seekers
summary: Move is part of effort by Trudeau government to address rise in asylum seekers ahead of election this fall. OTTAWA-Canada plans to make it harder for some asylum seekers to file claims for protection after entering the country from the U.S., part of an effort by the incumbent Liberal government to address a rise in refugee claimants.

title: Oil Inches Lower From Five-Month High Ahead of Inventories
summary: Crude falls alongside stocks after the IMF cut its estimates for global economic growth in 2019. • Oil prices swung between small gains and losses before ending lower Tuesday, wobbling near five-month highs, as investors weighed the latest supply signals and looked ahead to the latest reading on U.S. stockpiles.

title: New World Bank Head Vows to Uphold Climate-Change Policies
summary: Malpass says he will support policies to prohibit coal power plants. WASHINGTON-New World Bank President David Malpass said Tuesday he will support policies prohibiting financing of coal power plants as part of the institution's efforts to combat climate change.

title: 'The Tale of Genji: A Japanese Classic Illuminated' Review: An Ancient Story Continually Reinvented
summary: An expansive show at the Met shows the myriad ways in which a work that many consider to be the world's first novel has been interpreted over the centuries..

title: Grant Dispute Strands Some Long Islanders With Higher Tax Bills
summary: Suffolk County homeowners are told grants they received for new septic systems are taxable income. It was supposed to be a simple home-improvement project to help water quality on Long Island's East End. Instead, some residents are fuming about its unexpected consequence: Larger-than-expected tax bills.

title: Mnuchin Cautions on Brexit and U.S. Debt Default at House Hearing
summary: Treasury secretary says U.S. is carefully monitoring Brexit situation. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin told lawmakers Tuesday that U.S. financial institutions were prepared for the prospect of a disorderly Brexit, but said it would likely cause significant market and trade disruptions.

title: IMF Cuts 2019 Global Growth Outlook
summary: All major economies and most big emerging-market economies are deteriorating. Global economic growth in 2019 is off to a worse start than was apparent earlier in the year, with nearly the entire world economy stumbling, according to new forecasts from the International Monetary Fund.

title: American Airlines Trims Unit Revenue Outlook
summary: Government shutdown and grounding of 737 MAX aircraft have weighed on results. American Airlines Group Inc. lowered unit revenue expectations for the first quarter as the government shutdown and the grounding of several of its aircraft, including 737 MAX planes, weighed on its results.

title: Man Claiming He Was Missing Boy Timmothy Pitzen Detained by Judge Without Bond
summary: Brian Rini faces up to eight years in prison on charge of lying in an investigation about possible child sex trafficking. An Ohio man who claimed last week to be a missing child was ordered Tuesday by a federal magistrate judge in Cincinnati to be detained without bond pending a trial.

title: 'The EVE Project' Review: The Mother of Martha Graham Dance Company Themes
summary: The troupe's run at the Joyce Theater is a celebration of the feminine, including a New York premiere that deserves a lasting spot in its repertory..

title: EU Strong-Arms China Into Trade Promises
summary: Europe clinches new vows from China on technology transfer, state subsidies as Beijing-Washington talks continue. BRUSSELS-The European Union-China summit here Tuesday was meant to bolster cooperation, especially against controversial policies of President Trump. Instead, it is highlighting differences, led by growing trade tensions.

title: U.S. Government Bonds Climb Amid Trade Concerns
summary: Yields fall as Trump administration threatens to impose new tariffs on EU. U.S. government bond prices rose as investors assessed the fallout from a Trump administration threat to impose new tariffs on the European Union.

title: How T. Rex's 'Get It On' Launched Glam Rock
summary: Resume Subscription. Cocky and camp, T. Rex's "Get It On" was glam rock's first global hit in 1971. That year, the group's singer-guitarist and songwriter Marc Bolan performed the song on BBC TV's "Top of the Pops" in a gray satin jacket, pink pants and silver glitter teardrops under each eye.

title: Bank of America to Raise Minimum Wage to $20 an Hour by 2021
summary: Bank is increasing minimum wage to $17 an hour in May. Bank of America Corp. said it is raising the minimum wage so it hits $20 an hour in 2021.

title: U.K. Wants Another Brexit Extension, EU Wants Assurances
summary: European officials say the length of an extension is under discussion-and is likely to come with strings attached. European Union leaders are preparing to grant British Prime Minister Theresa May more time, at a summit Wednesday, to win backing in Parliament for an agreement to leave the bloc.

title: Sixteen Parents Indicted in College Admissions Scandal
summary: Parents, including actress Lori Loughlin, now face charge of money-laundering conspiracy. A federal grand jury in Boston indicted 16 parents allegedly involved in the college-admissions cheating scheme on two felony counts, a day after the U.S. Attorney's Office said 13 others would plead guilty to a single charge.

title: Moon Heads to White House Aiming to End North Korea Impasse
summary: South Korean president, meeting Trump on Thursday, looks to revive momentum for nuclear talks. SEOUL-South Korea's president, who played peacemaker by bringing the North Korean regime to talks with his U.S. ally, now faces the challenge of persuading both sides to make concessions he argues can help get Kim Jong Un to give up his nuclear arsenal.

title: Cerner Reaches Deal With Starboard to Add Board Members
summary: Health-care technology firm approves buying back additional $1.2 billion of common shares. Cerner Corp. said it has agreed with activist investor Starboard Value LP to add four board members and set out certain operating-margin goals.

title: PG&E Among Utilities Cited for Failing to Protect Against Attacks
summary: Cases, newly revealed but years old, raise questions about system aimed at encouraging self-disclosure by keeping names of violators under wraps. DTE Energy Co. , PG&E Corp. and a municipal utility in Missouri broke rules designed to protect the nation's electric system from cyber and physical attacks and were sanctioned by federal regulators, according to newly released documents and people knowledgeable about the cases.

title: Talk About a No Wynn Situation
summary: Wynn Resorts quickly folded its hand after the whole world got a peek at a bid for an Australian casino company. You've got to know when to hold 'em, know when to fold 'em.

title: Department Store Chain Debenhams Sells Itself as Pressure Builds on U.K. High Street
summary: Lenders take control of business, which plans to close some stores. U.K. department store operator Debenhams PLC said it has sold the business to its lenders, a move that comes as falling consumer spending, uncertainty around Brexit and rising competition from online retailers put the U.K.'s High Street retailers under pressure.

title: U.S. Says Jet-Tariffs Threat Isn't Tied to Broad EU Trade Push
summary: Trade official says move is tied to a longtime dispute before WTO between Boeing and Airbus. The Trump administration sought to play down the broader significance of a new plan to impose tariffs on $11.2 billion in imports from the European Union, saying the move is part of a distinct dispute over aviation subsidies rather than an effort to apply pressure in fraught negotiations toward a possible EU trade deal.

title: Cancer Risk Factors and the Roundup Cases
summary: Large, well-controlled epidemiology studies cannot assess the actual risk faced by an individual. Kudos to Dr. Arthur W. Lambert for "What Causes Cancer? It's Complicated" (op-ed, April 2) on the possible causes of cancer in the Roundup case. However, it should be emphasized that even if humans moved en masse to another planet with zero environmental carcinogens, cancer would still exist. Biological processes cannot be perfect, and work from Cristian Tomasetti and Bert Vogelstein from Johns Hopkins a few years ago showed that up to two-thirds of human cancers may be due to DNA replication errors that cannot be avoided as we all grow and then age. Of course it's up to us to reduce the remaining third by avoiding tobacco and other proven carcinogens.

title: Now Is the Time for U.S. to Support Taiwan
summary: War over Taiwan isn't inevitable. The best way to defend the democratic island from an unprovoked attack is for Washington to provide the next-generation jet fighters and allow Taiwan to defend itself.. Regarding your editorial "Tension Over the Taiwan Strait" (April 2): The cross-strait military balance has shifted significantly in China's favor. China has upward of 1,500 ballistic missiles based in Fujian province, directly across the narrow strait from Taiwan. Beijing would likely start with a naval and air blockade of Taiwan, with coordinated massive missile strikes on key island infrastructures. At the same time, China would launch cyberstrikes on Taiwan's computer, early warning, and communications networks. The Taiwanese military is woefully undermanned, unable to supply a bare minimum of soldiers to defend the island and is drastically short of all kinds of weaponry and armaments needed to defend itself against China.

title: The Mess at the Border Suits the Democrats
summary: The Democrats don't want a solution to border insecurity. They want the eventual votes of the people crossing the border. Finding a solution to stem the tide doesn't fit their agenda. That has become all too clear over decades.. Regarding your editorial "Blowing Up the Border" (April 3): The Democrats don't want a solution to border insecurity. They want the eventual votes of the people crossing the border. Finding a solution to stem the tide doesn't fit their agenda. That has become all too clear over decades. President Trump finds himself stymied by this "do nothingness." Your admonition to keep pressure on Democrats is way overdue. Even former Director of Homeland Security Jeh Johnson admitted there is a crisis. There is little room left for meaningful action. Democrats are the reason for this level of reaction by the president.

title: Not All Americans Are So Fiercely, Divisively Extreme
summary: The "Two Americas" are not the majority of Americans and represent only the loudest members of each party.. Regarding Peggy Noonan's "The Two Americas Have Grown Much Fiercer," (Declarations, March 30): Ms. Noonan makes a mistake assuming the "Two Americas" she mentions represent the entire general public. The "Two Americas" are not the majority of Americans and represent only the loudest members of each party. The media perpetuate this narrative that America is split, and that animosity and disunity are at dangerous levels within members of the working class, who do not care about the hyperpartisan tensions seen in the news. For them, a strong economy and maintaining a safe environment for themselves and their children are most important.

title: Standard Chartered to Pay $1.1 Billion in Iran Sanctions Settlement
summary: The bank took a $900 million provision earlier this year to help cover the settlement of the long-running probe. Standard Chartered PLC on Tuesday agreed to pay $1.1 billion to settle allegations it violated sanctions on Iran and other countries, marking the end of a long-running probe by U.S. and U.K. regulators that had weighed on the bank's share price.

title: Where Has Joe Biden Been for the Last Few Decades?
summary: For at least 10 years before my retirement in 2011 I, and all federal employees, were required to undergo mandatory sexual harassment and hostile work environment training.. Regarding your editorial "Joe Biden's Identity Reckoning" (April 2): Where has Uncle Joe been for the last 20-plus years?

title: Literature Offers Wisdom Beyond Today's Fixations
summary: Can't we teach great literature as literature without pressing it into service to make such hackneyed and obvious points.. Paula Marantz Cohen's "What 'Othello' Can Teach Us All," (op-ed, April 5) made me cringe. Can't we teach great literature as literature without pressing it into service to make such hackneyed and obvious points as that we should be "fairer and more generous toward those whom we might dismiss or pigeonhole" and "more forgiving of others' trespasses"?

title: This Brilliant Pasta Recipe Is So Much Faster Than Takeout
summary: No need to run to the market. You almost certainly have the ingredients on hand for chef Jonathan Benno's 15-minute spaghetti with garlic, olive oil and red chile flakes. EVERY COOK SHOULD have a low-maintenance recipe like this one on file. A graduate of Michelin-starred kitchens and currently at the helm of Benno, a fine-dining destination in Manhattan, chef Jonathan Benno is no exception. "This is a Tuesday-night pasta," he said of his second Slow Food Fast contribution, a spaghetti con aglio, olio e peperoncino. That translates as spaghetti with garlic, olive oil and red chile flakes, and the recipe calls for little more.

title: Why LBJ Biographer Robert Caro Still Writes 1000-Page Books by Hand
summary: Be it a Smith Corona typewriter or Chopin, thick pencils or a classic Buick, for the lionized biographer of LBJ, every thing has a purpose (and a story). LEANING AGAINST the filing cabinets in his New York office, poring through a folio of interviews with a former Lyndon Johnson aide, presidential biographer Robert Caro wistfully recalled a time he could dial up a White House staffer and ask simply: "'When Johnson was talking to George Wallace, was he on the sofa or the rocking chair?' And he'd have an answer."

title: Jennifer Aniston and Brad Pitt's Onetime Home Lists for $56 Million
summary: The then-couple spent more than three years remodeling the Beverly Hills property, which was designed by Golden Age architect Wallace Neff. A Beverly Hills estate designed by Hollywood architect Wallace Neff and extensively remodeled decades later by then-owners Jennifer Aniston and Brad Pitt, is coming on the market for $56 million.

title: A Beverly Hills Estate Built for Hollywood Royalty
summary: Designed by Wallace Neff, this Beverly Hills home was heavily remodeled decades later by then-couple Jennifer Aniston and Brad Pitt.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: China's Banks Are Choking on Coal Dust
summary: Is Chinese coal consumption in terminal decline, or ramping up again? The fortunes of the global coal industry-and of attempts to limit carbon emissions-could depend on the answer.. Is Chinese coal consumption in terminal decline or ramping up again? The fortunes of the global coal mining industry, and of attempts to limit global carbon emissions, could depend on the answer.

title: House Flipping Is Back to Pre-Crisis Levels. Here's Why It's Less of a Concern.
summary: Flippers today have much larger profit margins than those at the peak of the previous housing cycle. House flipping is back to nearly the same level it was around the 2006 peak of the housing boom, when it became a symbol of the rampant speculation that soared before the bubble burst.

title: Saudi Aramco Raises $12 Billion in Debut Bond Sale
summary: Investor interest will be an important bellwether for the oil giant's initial public offering. Saudi Aramco raised $12 billion in its debut international bond Tuesday, according to people familiar with the sale, an issuance that sparked massive interest among investors eager to access the world's most profitable company.

title: The Real Berlin: A Traveler's Journey Beyond the Grim Spy Clichés
summary: Nigerian novelist Helon Habila on the year he and his family moved from Virginia to Germany-and found a friendlier city than stereotypes suggest. WE ARRIVED IN BERLIN in the summer of 2013. It wasn't my first time in the city-I had been to a literature festival a few years earlier, and before that I went for research, each visit just a couple of days. I felt that I could never get used to the wide, cold and empty streets, and the people who always seemed to have a frown on their faces. I grew up in Nigeria, a former British colony, and many of my encounters with Germans were in spy novels and thrillers, by British and American authors, where Germans tended to be the villains. A lot of that perception still lingered in my psyche. When I told my wife I'd been offered a writing fellowship and we'd be spending a year in Berlin, her response was: "One year in Berlin, doing what?" It was a big gamble, uprooting our three young kids from Virginia where we'd lived for six years, and moving them to a country where we didn't speak the language or had any relations or friends.

title: Oil-Rich Kazakhstan Calls Snap Election
summary: Vote will be the first since autocrat Nursultan Nazarbayev said he was stepping down. ALMATY, Kazakhstan-Kazakhstan's interim president called snap elections Tuesday, the latest step in a carefully choreographed transition meant to select a new leader for Central Asia's biggest oil and gas producer, even as its first president maneuvers to hold on to power from behind the scenes.

title: How to Wear a Pussycat Blouse Like a Rock Muse
summary: As Anita Pallenberg proved, the bow-necked classic wasn't always so prim. AS A SELF-IDENTIFYING minimalist, it's perhaps surprising that I've never met a bow or ruffle I didn't like. I blame my mother, who dressed me in Laura Ashley dresses and frilly ankle socks trimmed with bows.

title: Jordan Spieth, Master of the Masters, Is Searching for His Game
summary: The 2015 champion has fallen to No. 33 in the world; 'Who knows if he'll ever find his way back?'. AUGUSTA, Ga.- There were no spectators watching the first time Jordan Spieth played Augusta National Golf Club. But as a guest of a member in the fall of 2013, he could see immediately how it would suit him. It was much hillier than it looked on television, requiring more imagination and adaptation than technical perfection.

title: Three Americans Killed in Taliban Blast Were Marines, Officials Say
summary: A civilian contractor thought to have been killed in the blast has been found alive. WASHINGTON-The three U.S. servicemembers killed Monday in a Taliban attack in Afghanistan were members of the Marine Corps, U.S. military officials said.

title: A Slippery Slope for Yield Chasers
summary: The steep selloff in an oil royalty trust shows the perils of focusing on yield in a depleting asset.. Chasing yield is never advisable. BP Prudhoe Bay Royalty Trust , an obscure financial instrument that throws off cash from BP's Alaskan oil fields, provides another reminder. It crushed investors Monday when it cut payouts despite underlying strength.

title: Job Openings Fell by More Than 500,000 in February
summary: Available jobs declined to lowest level since March 2018. Job openings fell in February to the lowest level in nearly a year, a sign that demand for workers eased modestly during a month when hiring fell sharply.

title: Yogurt Sales Sour as Options Proliferate
summary: Consumers face confusion as more varieties hit the market; 'Can I just get some strawberry?'. Yogurt's big sales run has expired.

title: Ditech Bankruptcy Could Block Homeowners From Pursuing Damages
summary: Consumer advocates fear the mortgage-servicing company could avoid paying for alleged violations because of a legal loophole. Homeowners who say mortgage servicer Ditech Holding Corp. mishandled their payments and charged illegal fees could be blocked from collecting damages because of the company's bankruptcy, despite a 2005 law aimed at preventing such an outcome.

title: Hong Kong Pro-Democracy Activists Convicted Over Protests
summary: Early architects of Umbrella Movement are among nine found guilty of public nuisance. HONG KONG-The early architects of Hong Kong's 2014 pro-democracy protests were found guilty of public-nuisance charges, in one of the final legal cases to emerge from a period of civil disobedience that brought increasing pressure from Beijing.

title: Welcome to Your Home on Mars
summary: Never mind how to get there-what will we live in on the Red Planet? Personal Tech columnist David Pierce examines designs from Bjarke Ingels, Foster + Partners and others.. Mars has a lot going for it, habitability-wise. Many big challenges remain, of course, but scientists believe there's plenty of potentially usable water, and an atmosphere close enough to our own to ultimately sustain life-with the right gear.

title: Wee Wee Pad Inventor Lists Fifth Avenue Spread for $39.95 Million
summary: Pet product entrepreneur Allen Simon is selling his full-floor unit that boasts a private elevator vestibule, Central Park views and a library with gold-leaf ceilings.. The inventor of the Wee Wee Pad-absorbent pads designed to be urinated on by dogs-is asking $39.95 million for his deluxe Fifth Avenue apartment.

title: Minnesota College Has a Portrait by 'The Scream' Painter-Or It Doesn't. Experts Won't Say.
summary: Resume Subscription. Officials at a small Midwestern college rejoiced when they learned the school owned what appeared to be an oil painting by Edvard Munch. Now they'd be excused if they wanted to scream.

title: Société Générale to Cut Jobs Amid Europe's Investment Banking Downturn
summary: French bank plans to cut 1,600 jobs world-wide. PARIS-French bank Société Générale SA said Tuesday it plans to cut nearly 1,600 jobs globally after a slump in investment banking revenue in the fourth quarter, retrenching to its core businesses as choppy markets hobble Europe's banks.

title: Wolfgang Puck Fled From Home to a Series of Kitchens as a Teen
summary: Spago's celebrity chef looks back at the challenges, adventures and mentors that changed his life and led him to the U.S.. Wolfgang Puck, 69, is a celebrity chef and restaurateur who helped pioneer California fusion cuisine starting in the early 1980s. He manages and operates 25 restaurants-including Spago-and oversees an additional 81 licensed locations world-wide. He spoke with Marc Myers.

title: Tommy Mottola Sells Greenwich Estate for 25% Off
summary: The music executive, who spent about three years designing and building the house, first listed the Connecticut property for $19.95 million in April, 2017.. Music executive Tommy Mottola has sold his Georgian-style Greenwich, Conn. estate for $14.875 million, or 25% off its original asking price.

summary: The chances of the Cavaliers' three straight comebacks from late-game deficits en route to winning the title were roughly 1 in 2,500. MINNEAPOLIS-Something was wrong. Virginia led Texas Tech by eight with less than six minutes to play in the national championship. It seemed far too easy. It was.

title: Deutsche Bank Squeezes Out Investors in Its Exchange-Traded Notes
summary: Delisting Thursday will leave remaining holders stranded and potentially facing steep losses. A dozen Deutsche Bank AG exchange-traded notes will soon join the ranks of the living dead, leaving investors in an unusual quandary.

title: Virginia-Texas Tech: A 'Crummy' Championship Turns Into a Classic
summary: The Cavaliers triumph over the Red Raiders as a predicted snoozer becomes a title game for the ages. Minneapolis

title: Singapore Ready to Supply Clean Ship Fuel
summary: The world's biggest refueling station says it will have enough low-sulfur fuel next year to meet new demand tied to emissions measures. Singapore, the world's largest maritime refueling port, said it will have an ample supply of cleaner fuel to meet an increase in demand next year, when the global commercial fleet will be required to cut sulfur emissions.

title: Wells Fargo Sells Institutional Retirement and Trust Arm
summary: Principal Financial's deal for the unit to close in the third quarter. Wells Fargo & Co. is selling off its retirement and trust business to Principal Financial Group for $1.2 billion, the companies said Tuesday.

title: Stocks to Watch: Twitter, Zogenix, Symantec, Wynn Resorts
summary: Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively Tuesday. Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Tuesday's session. Stock movements noted by ticker reflect movements during regular trading hours; premarket trading is specified separately.

title: Five Years After Cancer Warnings, Hysterectomy Tool Still In Use
summary: A debate simmers about whether morcellators are safe after FDA stopped short of a ban. Piedmont Atlanta Hospital lets gynecologists use laparoscopic power morcellators with informed consent from patients. In the same city, Emory Healthcare has halted use of the gynecological cutting tools, which regulators have warned can spread hidden cancers, in its hospitals.

title: Carlos Ghosn Assails Nissan Executives for Playing a 'Dirty Game'
summary: The former chairman of Nissan and Renault was rearrested before he could hold a news conference. TOKYO-Carlos Ghosn blamed backstabbing Nissan Motor Co. colleagues for the charges he now faces, saying they feared a merger with partner Renault SA .

title: 7 Sorbet-Colored Pieces Your Wardrobe's Craving
summary: Spring gets sweeter with soft shades like Creamsicle orange, lemon yellow and watermelon pink. All-yellow sunnies make for a surprising statement accessory. Oliver Peoples sunglasses, $385, Oliver Peoples, 366 West Broadway, New York

title: As Afghan War Drags On, EU Offers Greater Role in Brokering Peace
summary: Willingness of the U.S. to accept an EU-sponsored channel for discussions with Iran on Afghanistan is sign of Washington's hunger for a political settlement to the 18-year conflict. The European Union is prepared to step up its role in the Afghan peace process, offering to serve as a guarantor of a negotiated settlement of the 18-year war and to bring Iran more directly into deliberations over an accord.

title: Do the Latest Baby Monitors Ease Fears or Add Anxiety?
summary: Tech companies promise to track your baby's bedtime well-being so you can follow that longstanding parenting adage: Sleep when the baby sleeps. But advanced baby monitors like Owlet and Angelcare are causing parental anxiety, too.. Hovering over a sleeping newborn, watching for the reassuring sign of his or her tiny chest rising and falling, is a parental rite of passage. It's the most terrifying and primal part of caring for a new life: Will my baby survive the night?

title: U.S. Moves to Impose Tariffs on $11 Billion of EU Goods
summary: Trump administration says the proposed tariffs are in response to the bloc's subsidies for Boeing rival Airbus. The Trump administration moved Monday toward imposing tariffs on about $11 billion in imports from the European Union, saying the move was justified by the bloc's subsidies for European aircraft manufacturer Airbus.

title: The Hunt for Alien Life Starts in Earth's Most Extreme Places
summary: Resume Subscription. Microbiologist Jill Mikucki went to Antarctica last year on a special mission: She was looking for signs of what life on other planets and moons might look like. Her work is part of an effort to understand the origins of life-not just in our world, but in the solar system-by examining the organisms that thrive in Earth's most extreme environments.

title: U.S. Goes on the Offensive Against China's Empire-Building Funding Plan
summary: American experts helped Myanmar push back on multibillion-dollar port deal in new strategy to counter China's Belt and Road influence. Last year, Myanmar renegotiated terms for a multibillion-dollar Chinese-funded deep-water port and industrial zone, shrinking the scope of the project and slashing the country's future debt burden to its economic powerhouse neighbor.

title: UBS Fired Senior Investment Banker Over Buyout Loan
summary: Episode shows how government crackdown on leveraged lending continues to roil banks. UBS Group AG fired a senior investment banker because he allegedly failed to apprise his managers of details of a leveraged-buyout loan, highlighting the pressure Wall Street firms are under to keep a lid on risk in the lucrative business.

title: Brexit Woes Dim Northern Ireland Property Market
summary: Many fear prospect of hard border in Ireland, which could severely hurt commerce on the island and beyond. Uncertainty over Brexit is spilling into the commercial real-estate market in Northern Ireland, which looks especially vulnerable to an adverse outcome of the U.K.'s exit negotiations with the European Union.

summary: Israelis cast ballots in tight race between incumbent Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his rival, Benny Gantz. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Don't Count on a Hollywood Showdown at Sony
summary: Resume Subscription. Activist investor Daniel Loeb seems to be taking aim at Sony for the second time in six years. He failed to rally support for a spinoff of movie and music assets in 2013, and he may fail again.

title: Facebook Bends to EU Pressure on 'Misleading' Fine Print
summary: Social-media giant has agreed to spell out more clearly for users how it monetizes their data. Facebook Inc. has bowed to demands from European Union regulators to change what the bloc had called misleading terms of service, the latest example of efforts by governments globally to exercise more control over tech firms.

title: Wells Fargo, Languishing for Two Years, Struggles to Boost Businesses
summary: Scandals tainted the bank's image; underneath, its units are also burdened. Wells Fargo & Co.'s reputation has languished over the past 2½ years. Its key businesses aren't doing much better.

title: Virginia Wins NCAA Men's Basketball Championship
summary: The Cavaliers beat Texas Tech, 85-77, in overtime to win their first national championship. MINNEAPOLIS-Virginia overcame the worst possible ending to a season by creating the best ending in program history.

title: Tokyo's Tax Increase Would Undermine All of Japan's Economic Progress
summary: Japan's pursuit of a tighter fiscal stance runs in the face of the clear risks to its economic outlook. Japan's economy is weakening, but the government looks likely to increase its sales tax. It should scrap the change and preserve the economic progress made in recent years.

title: Walmart Rolls Out the Robots
summary: Retailer to expand use of machines to scan shelves and scrub floors as it seeks to keep labor costs down. Walmart Inc. is expanding its use of robots in stores to help monitor inventory, clean floors and unload trucks, part of the retail giant's efforts to control labor costs as it spends more to raise wages and offer new services like online grocery delivery.

title: Roundup, the World's Best-Selling Weedkiller, Faces a Legal Reckoning
summary: Resume Subscription. For years, scientists at Monsanto Co. worked closely with outside researchers on studies that concluded its Roundup weedkiller was safe.

title: Judge Blocks Trump Administration Policy of Returning Asylum Seekers to Mexico
summary: Obama appointee finds no legal basis under current law for adopting the policy. A federal judge blocked a Trump administration policy of returning asylum-seeking Central Americans to Mexico while their requests for admission to the U.S. are adjudicated.

title: Pilots' Steps in Ethiopian Crash Prompt Questions
summary: System failure is considered the main culprit in the Ethiopian Airlines crash, but safety experts ask if the crew's actions contributed to the nose-dive. Crash investigators believe an automated flight-control system that went haywire led to last month's fatal crash of a Boeing Co. 737 MAX in Ethiopia. But some pilots, industry officials and air-safety experts are also raising questions about the actions of the cockpit crew as detailed in last week's preliminary accident report.

title: Trump Administration Blocks Baseball Players From Cuba
summary: Move reverses historic agreement meant to create path for Cuban players to join Major League Baseball without enlisting human traffickers. The Trump administration blocked Major League Baseball from signing players directly from Cuba to play professionally in the U.S., nullifying a historic deal the league struck in December with the island nation's baseball federation.

title: Wynn Resorts Bids $7.1 Billion for Australia's Crown Resorts
summary: Global gaming companies look to get bigger as they try to fend off online gambling. SYDNEY- Wynn Resorts Ltd. of Las Vegas offered to buy Australia's Crown Resorts Ltd. for about $7.1 billion, in the latest sign that global gambling companies are looking to get bigger as they battle with online gaming.

title: Bank Chiefs to Tell Congress: Financial System Is Much Safer
summary: Chiefs, facing skeptical House Democrats, cite postcrisis reforms and improved culture. WASHINGTON-The chief executives of the largest U.S. banks plan to tell Congress this week that the financial system is less risky and more tightly supervised than it was a decade ago thanks to a series of regulatory reforms implemented in the wake of the 2008 financial crisis.

title: Prosecutors Net 14 Guilty Plea Agreements in College-Cheat Probe
summary: Actress Felicity Huffman among parents to plead guilty in admissions-fraud scandal as investigation continues. Thirteen parents and one college coach agreed to plead guilty for their roles in the college-admissions cheating scandal, a turning point in the case and a likely first step toward at least some of the parents serving prison time for attempting to secure spots for their children at elite colleges.

title: Baltimore City Council Calls for Mayor Catherine Pugh to Resign
summary: Pressure mounts on Democrat amid investigations into her 'Healthy Holly' book deals. BALTIMORE-Nearly the entire Baltimore City Council called for Mayor Catherine Pugh to resign, ratcheting up pressure on the Democrat over revelations she grossed hundreds of thousands of dollars selling her "Healthy Holly" children's books to businesses, including some that benefited from her official actions.

title: Fed Moves to Ease 'Living Wills' for Large Banks
summary: Under proposal, largest U.S. banks would file full plans every four years, rather than annually. Federal regulators proposed easing a rule that required big banks to plan annually for their own demise, the latest move by regulators under President Trump to loosen controls put in place after the financial crisis.
